It is graded to different sizes, and designated by the name of the type that it matches; as, nonpareil reglet, pica reglet, and the like.
Any dry dehiscent fruit.
Of or pertaining to the reign of a monarch; as, regnal years.
The condition or quality of being regnant; sovereignty; rule.
Having the chief power; ruling; predominant; prevalent.
To swallow again; to swallow back.
To grant back; to grant again or anew.
A renewed of a grant; as, the regrant of a monopoly.
To offend; to shock.
The act or practice of regrating.
A returning or giving of thanks.
To go back; to retrograde, as the apsis of a planet's orbit.
The act of passing back; passage back; return; retrogression. "The progress or regress of man".
The power or liberty of passing back.

Pain of mind on account of something done or experienced in the past, with a wish that it had been different; a looking back with dissatisfaction or with longing; grief; sorrow; especially, a mourning on account of the loss of some joy, advantage, or satisfaction.

Conformed to a rule; agreeable to an established rule, law, principle, or type, or to established customary forms; normal; symmetrical; as, a regular verse in poetry; a regular piece of music; a regular verb; regular practice of law or medicine; a regular building.
A soldier belonging to a permanent or standing army; -- chiefly used in the plural.
The condition or quality of being regular; as, regularity of outline; the regularity of motion.
To cause to become regular; to regulate.
In a regular manner; in uniform order; methodically; in due order or time.
A rule or order prescribed for management or government; prescription; a regulating principle; a governing direction; precept; law; as, the regulations of a society or a school.
Necessarily assumed by the mind as fundamental to all other knowledge; furnishing fundamental principles; as, the regulative principles, or principles a priori; the regulative faculty.

A contrivance for regulating and controlling motion, as: (a) The lever or index in a watch, which controls the effective length of the hairspring, and thus regulates the vibrations of the balance. (b) The governor of a steam engine. (c) A valve for controlling the admission of steam to the steam chest, in a locomotive.
To reduce to regulus; to separate, as a metal from extraneous matter; as, to regulize antimony.
A petty king; a ruler of little power or consequence.
The button, globule, or mass of metal, in a more or less impure state, which forms in the bottom of the crucible in smelting and reduction of ores.
To be thrown or poured back; to rush or surge back.
The act of swallowing again; reabsorption.
Something hashed over, or made up from old materials.
To hear again; to try a second time; as, to rehear a cause in Chancery.
The act of rehearsing; recital; narration; repetition; specifically, a private recital, performance, or season of practice, in preparation for a public exhibition or exercise.
To revive; to cheer; to cherish.
Of or relating to rehibition; as, a rehibitory action.
A portuguese money of account, in value about one tenth of a cent.
The parliament of Austria (exclusive of Hungary, which has its own diet, or parliament). It consists of an Upper and a Lower House, or a House of Lords and a House of Representatives.
A free city of the former German empire.
The Diet, or House of Representatives, of the German empire, which is composed of members elected for a term of three years by the direct vote of the people. See Bundesrath.
A hollow cut or channel for quiding anything; as, the reigle of a side post for a flood gate.
To light again; to cause to shine anew; to relume; to reillumine.
The act or process of enlightening again.
To illumine again or anew; to reillume.
A strip of oxhide, deprived of hair, and rendered pliable, -- used for twisting into ropes, etc.
To make restoration or payment of an equivalent to (a person); to pay back to; to indemnify; -- often reflexive; as, to reimburse one's self by successful speculation.
To import again; to import what has been exported; to bring back.
To impregnate again or anew.
A second or repeated impression; a reprint.
The act of reimprisoning, or the state of being reimprisoned.
The strap of a bridle, fastened to the curb or snaffle on each side, by which the rider or driver governs the horse.
Hence, an instrument or means of curbing, restraining, or governing; government; restraint.
To restrain; to control; to check.

Any ruminant of the genus Rangifer, of the Deer family, found in the colder parts of both the Eastern and Western hemispheres, and having long irregularly branched antlers, with the brow tines palmate.
A name given to many different kinds of apples, mostly of French origin.
See Re\'89nforce, v. t.
To flow in anew.
The kidneys; also, the region of the kidneys; the loins.
The inward impulses; the affections and passions; -- so called because formerly supposed to have their seat in the part of the body where the kidneys are.
The act of reinserting.
The act of reinspecting.
To place again in possession, or in a former state; to restore to a state from which one had been removed; to instate again; as, to reinstate a king in the possession of the kingdom.
Insurance a second time or again; renewed insurance.
A contract by which an insurer is insured wholly or in part against the risk he has incurred in insuring somebody else. See Reassurance.
To insure, as life or property, in favor of one who has taken an inssurance risk upon it.
To renew with regard to any state or quality; to restore; to bring again together into a whole, as the parts off anything; to reas, to reintegrate a nation.
To interrogate again; to question repeatedly.
To invest again or anew.
The act of investing anew; a second or repeated investment.
The word is used as a Portuguese designation of money of account, one hundred reis being about equal in value to eleven cents.
A common title in the East for a person in authority, especially the captain of a ship.
A title formerly given to one of the chief Turkish officers of state.  He was chancellor of the empire, etc.
The thin membrane which separates the canal of the cochlea from the vestibular scala in the internal ear.
Capable of being reissued.
To issue a second time.
A second or repeated issue.
A German cavalry soldier of the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries.
The act of reiterating; that which is reiterated.
A word expressing repeated or reiterated action.
A word formed from another, or used to form another, by repetition; as, dillydally.
To cast from one; to throw away; to discard.
Things thrown out or away; especially, things excreted by a living organism.
Act of rejecting, or state of being rejected.
Implying or requiring rejection; rejectable.
Act of rejecting; matter rejected, or thrown away.
To give joi to; to make joyful; to gladden.
The expression of joy or gladness.
To join again; to unite after separation.
To come, or go, again into the presence of; to join the company of again.
To answer, as the defendant to the plaintiff's replication.
The defendant's answer to the plaintiff's replication.
Act of joining again. [Obs.] "Beguiles our lips of all rejoindure" (i.e., kisses).
Specifically (Arch.), to fill up the joints of, as stones in buildings when the mortar has been dislodged by age and the action of the weather.
To judge again; to re<?/xamine; to review; to call to a new trial and decision.
A renewing of youth; the state of being or growing young again.

A method of cell formation in which the entire protoplasm of an old cell escapes by rupture of the cell wall, and then develops a new cell wall. It is seen sometimes in the formation of zo<?/spores, etc.
Becoming, or causing to become, rejuvenated; rejuvenating.
imp. & p. p. of Relay.
A narrow space between the foot of the rampart and the scarp of the ditch, serving to receive the earth that may crumble off or be washed down, and prevent its falling into the ditch.
To go on shore after having embarked; to land again.
To slip or slide back, in a literal sense; to turn back.

To slide or turn back into a former state or practice; to fall back from some condition attained; -- generally in a bad sense, as from a state of convalescence or amended condition; as, to relaps into a stupor, into vice, or into barbarism; -- sometimes in a good sense; as, to relapse into slumber after being disturbed.
To make reference; to take account.
Standing in relation or connection; as, the electric and magnetic forcec are closely related.
The act of relating or telling; also, that which is related; recital; account; narration; narrative; as, the relation of historical events.

The state of being related or of referring; what is apprehended as appertaining to a being or quality, by considering it in its bearing upon something else; relative quality or condition; the being such and such with regard or respect to some other thing; connection; as, the relation of experience to knowledge; the relation of master to servant.
Indicating or specifying some relation.
The state of being related by kindred, affinity, or other alliance.
In a relative manner; in relation or respect to something else; not absolutely.
The state of being relative; as, the relativity of a subject.
A private person at whose relation, or in whose behalf, the attorney-general allows an information in the nature of a quo warranto to be filed.
To make lax or loose; to make less close, firm, rigid, tense, or the like; to slacken; to loosen; to open; as, to relax a rope or cord; to relax the muscles or sinews.
To abate in severity; to become less rigorous.
Capable of being relaxed.
A medicine that relaxes; a laxative.
The act or process of relaxing, or the state of being relaxed; as, relaxation of the muscles; relaxation of a law.
Remission from attention and effort; indulgence in recreation, diversion, or amusement.

A supply of anything arranged beforehand for affording relief from time to time, or at successive stages; provision for successive relief. Specifically: (a) A supply of horses placced at stations to be in readiness to relieve others, so that a trveler may proceed without delay. (b) A supply of hunting dogs or horses kept in readiness at certain places to relive the tired dogs or horses, and to continnue the pursuit of the game if it comes that way. (c) A number of men who relieve others in carrying on some work.

In various forms of telegrapfhic apparatus, a megnet which receives the circuit current, and is caused by it to bring into into action the power of a local battery for performing the work of making the record; also, a similar device by which the current in one circuit is made to open or close another circuit in which a current is passing.
That may be released.
To lease again; to grant a new lease of; to let back.
To let loose again; to set free from restraint, confinement, or servitude; to give liberty to, or to set at liberty; to let go.
To relieve from something that confines, burdens, or oppresses, as from pain, trouble, obligation, penalty.
Relief from care, pain, or any burden.
The act of releasing, as from confinement or obligation.
One by whom a release is given.
To remove, usually to an inferior position; to consign; to transfer; specifically, to send into exile; to banish.
To become less rigid or hard; to yield; to dissolve; to melt; to deliquesce.
To soften; to dissolve.
To let anew, as a hous.
The quality or state of being relevant; pertinency; applicability.
Sufficiency to infer the conclusion.
Bearing upon, or properly applying to, the case in hand; pertinent; applicable.
A raising or lifting up.
The state or quality of being reliable; reliableness.
Suitable or fit to be relied on; worthy of dependance or reliance; trustworthy.
Anything on which to rely; dependence; ground of trust; as, the boat was a poor reliance.
That which remains; that which is left after loss or decay; a remaining portion; a remnant.
A woman whose husband is dead; a widow.
Destitute of relief; also, remediless.
Capable of being relieved; fitted to recieve relief.
To cause to seem to rise; to put in relief; to give prominence or conspicuousness to; to <?/et off by contrast.
One who, or that which, relieves.
Serving or tending to relieve.
To light or kindle anew.
A person bound by monastic vows; a nun; a monk.

The outward act or form by which men indicate their recognition of the existence of a god or of gods having power over their destiny, to whom obedience, service, and honor are due; the feeling or expression of human love, fear, or awe of some superhuman and overruling power, whether by profession of belief, by observance of rites and ceremonies, or by the conduct of life; a system of faith and worship; a manifestation of piety; as, ethical religions; monotheistic religions; natural religion; revealed religion; the religion of the Jews; the religion of idol worshipers.
The practice of, or devotion to, religion.
Affectation or pretense of religion.
The quality of being religious; religious feeling or sentiment; religiousness.
To withdraw from; to leave behind; to desist from; to abandon; to quit; as, to relinquish a pursuit.
The act of relinquishing.
A depositary, often a small box or casket, in which relics are kept.
Remains of the dead; organic remains; relics.
To liquidate anew; to adjust a second time.
A second or renewed liquidation; a renewed adjustment.
To live again; to revive.
To recall to life; to revive.
To load again, as a gun.
A second lending of the same thing; a renewal of a loan.
Renewal of a lease.
To love in return.
To struggle against anything; to resist; to oppose.

To stay behind while others withdraw; to be left after others have been removed or destroyed; to be left after a number or quantity has been subtracted or cut off; to be left as not included or comprised.
To recommit; to send back.
The state of being remanent; continuance; permanence.
To mark again, or a second time; to mark anew.
To mark in a notable manner; to distinquish clearly; to make noticeable or conspicuous; to piont out.
Act of remarking or attentively noticing; notice or observation.
A second or repeated marriage.
To furnish with a new mast or set of masts.
To chew or masticate again; to chew over and over, as the cud.
The act of masticating or chewing again or repeatedly.
Earth or materials made into a bank after having been excavated.
Not admitting of a remedy; incapable of being restored or corrected; incurable; irreparable; as, a remediless mistake or loss.
That which relieves or cures a disease; any medicine or application which puts an end to disease and restores health; -- with for; as, a remedy for the gout.

To have ( a notion or idea) come into the mind again, as previously perceived, known, or felt; to have a renewed apprehension of; to bring to mind again; to think of again; to recollect; as, I remember the fact; he remembers the events of his childhood; I cannot remember dates.

To be capable of recalling when required; to keep in mind; to be continually aware or thoughtful of; to preserve fresh in the memory; to attend to; to think of with gratitude, affection, respect, or any other emotion.
The act of remembering; a holding in mind, or bringing to mind; recollection.
The quill feathers of the wings of a bird.
To migrate again; to go back; to return.
Tending or adapted to remind; careful to remind.
Recalling to mind, or capable of recalling to mind; having remembrance; reminding one of something.
Of or pertaining to reminiscence, or remembrance.
An animal having limbs like oars, especially one of certain crustaceans.
To send, give, or grant back; torelease a claim to; to resign or surrender by deed; to return.

Not energetic or exact in duty or business; not careful or prompt in fulfilling engagements; negligent; careless; tardy; behindhand; lagging; slack; hence, lacking earnestness or activity; languid; slow.
Discharge from that which is due; relinquishment of a claim, right, or obligation; pardon of transgression; release from forfeiture, penalty, debt, etc.
Quality or state of being remiss.
Serving or tending to remit, or to secure remission; remissive.
To send money, as in payment.
The sum or thing remitted.
Remitting; characterized by remission; having remissions.

The sending or placing back of a person to a title or right he had before; the restitution of one who obtains possession of property under a defective title, to his rights under some valid title by virtue of which he might legally have entered into possession only by suit.
To mix again or repeatedly.
That which remains after a part is removed, destroyed, used up, performed, etc.; residue.
To modify again or anew; to reshape.
A kind of piquant sauce or salad dressing resembling mayonnaise.
To mold or shape anew or again; to reshape.
The act of remonetizing.
To restore to use as money; as, to remonetize silver.
The act of remonstrating
In a remonstrant manner.
To point out; to show clearly; to make plain or manifest; hence, to prove; to demonstrate.
Sympathetic sorrow; pity; compassion.
The opportunity of, or things necessary for, remounting; specifically, a fresh horse, with his equipments; as, to give one a remount.
Admitting of being removed.
The act of removing, or the state of being removed.
To move away from the position occupied; to cause to change place; to displace; as, to remove a building.
To pay an equivalent to for any service, loss, expense, or other sacrifice; to recompense; to requite; as, to remunerate men for labor.
That which is given to remunerate; an equivalent given, as for services, loss, or sufferings.
Of or pertaining to the kidneys; in the region of the kidneys.
To give a new name to.
A fox; -- so called in fables or familiar tales, and in poetry.
Of or pertaining to Renard, the fox, or the tales in which Renard is mentioned.
The state of being renascent.
Springing or rising again into being; being born again, or reproduced.
Born again; regenerate; renewed.
To deny; to disown.
Same as Rencounter, n.
To meet unexpectedly; to encounter.
To attack hand to hand.
A meeting of two persons or bodies; a collision; especially, a meetingg in opposition or contest; a combat, action, or engagement.
A causal combat or action; a sudden contest or fight without premeditation, as between individuals or small parties.
To return; to pay back; to restore.
To inflict, as a retribution; to requite.
To pass; to run; -- said of the passage of a rope through a block, eyelet, etc.; as, a rope renders well, that is, passes freely; also, to yield or give way.
A return; a payment of rent.
A vessel in which lard or tallow, etc., is rendered.
A place appointed for a meeting, or at which persons customarily meet.
Especially, the appointed place for troops, or for the ships of a fleet, to assemble; also, a place for enlistment.
To bring together at a certain place; to cause to be assembled.
Capable, or admitting, of being rendered.
The act of rendering; especially, the act of surrender, as of fugitives from justice, at the claim of a foreign government; also, surrender in war.
One faithless to principle or party.
One who deserts from a military or naval post; a deserter
To make new again; to restore to freshness, perfection, or vigor; to give new life to; to rejuvenate; to re<?/stablish; to recreate; to rebuild.
The quality or state of being renewable.
Capable of being renewed; as, a lease renewable at pleasure.
The state of being renewed.
One who, or that which, renews.
To deney; to reject; to renounce.
A rung or round of a ladder.
Having the form or shape of a kidney; as, a reniform mineral; a reniform leaf.
The state or quality of being renitent; resistance; reluctance.
To cast off or reject deliberately; to disown; to dismiss; to forswear.
The act of disclaiming or rejecting; renunciation.
To make over again; to restore to freshness or vigor; to renew.
The state of being much known and talked of; exalted reputation derived from the extensive praise of great achievements or accomplishments; fame; celebrity; -- always in a good sense.
One who gives renown.
Having great renown; famous.
A soft, compact variety of talc,, being an altered pyroxene. It is often worked in a lathe into inkstands and other articles.
An opening made by rending; a break or breach made by force; a tear.
Figuratively, a schim; a rupture of harmony; a separation; as, a rent in the church.
To take and hold under an agreement to pay rent; as, the tennant rents an estate of the owner.
Capable of being rented, or suitable for renting.
A schedule, account, or list of rents, with the names of the tenants, etc.; a rent roll.
A sum total of rents; as, an estate that yields a rental of ten thousand dollars a year.
One who rents or leases an estate; -- usually said of a lessee or tenant.
To sew together so that the seam is scarcely visible; to sew up with skill and nicety; to finedraw.
To restore the original design of, by working in new warp; -- said with reference to tapestry.
One who has a fixed income, as from lands, stocks, or the like.
The act of renouncing.
Formal declination to take out letters of administration, or to assume an office, privilege, or right.
That may be reobtained.
To ordain again, as when the first ordination is considered defective.
The act of reorganizing; a reorganized existence; as, reorganization of the troops.
To organize again or anew; as, to reorganize a society or an army.
A fabric made of silk or wool, or of silk and wool, and having a transversely corded or ribbed surface.
Formed with a surface closely corded, or ribbed transversely; -- applied to textile fabrics of silk or wool; as, rep silk.
To pace again; to walk over again in a contrary direction.
To pack a second time or anew; as, to repack beef; to repack a trunk.
To paganize anew; to bring back to paganism.
imp. & p. p. of Repay.
To paint anew or again; as, to repaint a house; to repaint the ground of a picture.
To go; to betake one's self; to resort; ass, to repair to sanctuary for safety.
Having a slightly undulating margin; -- said of leaves.
The quality or state of being reparable.
Capable of being repaired, restored to a sound or good state, or made good; restorable; as, a reparable injury.
In a reparable manner.
The act of renewing, restoring, etc., or the state of being renewed or repaired; as, the reparation of a bridge or of a highway; -- in this sense, repair is oftener used.
The act of making amends or giving satisfaction or compensation for a wrong, injury, etc.; also, the thing done or given; amends; satisfaction; indemnity.
To pass again; to pass or travel over in the opposite direction; to pass a second time; as, to repass a bridge or a river; to repass the sea.
To pass or go back; to move back; as, troops passing and repassing before our eyes.
The act of repassing; passage back.
The act of taking food.
That which is taken as food; a meal; figuratively, any refreshment.
Restoration to one's country.
To pay back; to refund; as, to repay money borrowed or advanced.
The act of repaying; reimbursement.
The money or other thing repaid.
Capable of being repealed.
Recall, as from banishment.
To go over again; to attempt, do, make, or utter again; to iterate; to recite; as, to repeat an effort, an order, or a poem.
That which is repeated; as, the repeat of a pattern; that is, the repetition of the engraved figure on a roller by which an impression is produced (as in calico printing, etc.).
One who, or that which, repeats.
The principle of repulsion; the quality or capacity of repelling; repulsion.
Driving back; able or tending to repel.
A remedy to repel from a tumefied part the fluids which render it tumid.
Prostrate and rooting; -- said of stems.
In a repentant manner.
The act of perceiving again; a repeated perception of the same object.
Rapid reiteration of the same sound.
Tending or able to repercuss; having the power of sending back; causing to reverberate.
A list of drams, operas, pieces, parts, etc., which a company or a person has rehearsed and is prepared to perform.
A place in which things are disposed in an orderly manner, so that they can be easily found, as the index of a book, a commonplace book, or the like.
The act of repeating; a doing or saying again; iteration.
Recital from memory; rehearsal.
To fail; to wane.
With repening or murmuring.
Any edible sea urchin.
To place again; to restore to a former place, position, condition, or the like.
To refund; to repay; to restore; as, to replace a sum of money borrowed.
Capable or admitting of being put back into a place.
Admitting of having its place supplied by a like thing or an equivalent; as, the lost book is replaceable.
The removal of an edge or an angle by one or more planes.
That may be planted again.
The act of planting again; a replanting.
A second pleading, or course of pleadings; also, the right of pleading again.
The act of replenishing, or the state of being replenished.
That which replenishes; supply.
The state of being replete.
The state of being replete; superabundant fullness.
Capable of being replevied.

A personal action which lies to recover possession of goods and chattle wrongfully taken or detained.  Originally, it was a remedy peculiar to cases for wrongful distress, but it may generally now be brought in all cases of wrongful taking or detention.
The writ by which goods and chattles are replevied.
A copy of a work of art, as of a picture or satue, made by the maker of the original.
Folded over or backward; folded back upon itself; as, a replicate leaf or petal; a replicate margin of a shell.
An answer; a reply.
To answer a defendant's plea.

To bring back, as an answer; to announce in return; to relate, as what has been discovered by a person sent to examine, explore, or investigate; as, a messenger reports to his employer what he has seen or ascertained; the committee reported progress.
To furnish in writing an account of a speech, the proceedings at a meeting, the particulars of an occurrence, etc., for publication.

One who reports. Specifically: (a) An officer or person who makees authorized statements of law proceedings and decisions, or of legislative debates. (b) One who reports speeches, the proceedings of public meetings, news, etc., for the newspapers.
Of or pertaining to a reporter or reporters; as, the reportorial staff of a newspaper.
The act or state of reposing; as, the reposal of a trust.
That on which one reposes.
Figuratively, to remain or abide restfully without anxiety or alarms.
Rest of mind; tranquillity; freedom from uneasiness; also, a composed manner or deportment.
Full of repose; quiet.
To cause to rest or stay; to lay away; to lodge, as for safety or preservation; to place; to store.
An instrument employed for replacing a displaced organ or part.
A place where things are or may be reposited, or laid up, for safety or preservation; a depository.
Formed in relief, as a pattern on metal.
Worthy of reprehension; culpable; censurable; blamable.
Reproof; censure; blame; disapproval.
To present again or anew; to present by means of something standing in the place of; to exhibit the counterpart or image of; to typify.
Fitted to represent; exhibiting a similitude.
Bearing the character or power of another; acting for another or others; as, a council representative of the people.
One who, or that which, represents (anything); that which exhibits a likeness or similitude.
The quality or state of being representative.
To press back or down effectually; to crush down or out; to quell; to subdue; to supress; as, to repress sedition or rebellion; to repress the first risings of discontent.
Hence, to check; to restrain; to keep back.
One who, or that which, represses.
Capable of being repressed.
The act of repressing, or state of being repressed; as, the repression of evil and evil doers.
To delay the punishment of; to suspend the execution of sentence on; to give a respite to; to respite; as, to reprieve a criminal for thirty days.
To reprove publicly and officially, in execution of a sentence; as, the court ordered him to be reprimanded.
A machine or implement for applying fresh primers to spent cartridge shells, so that the shells be used again.
To print again; to print a second or a new edition of.
To renew the impression of.
The act of taking from an enemy by way of reteliation or indemnity.
Anything taken from an enemy in retaliation.
A taking by way of retaliation.
To recompense; to pay.
To come back to, or come home to, as a matter of blame; to bring shame or disgrace upon; to disgrace.
The act of reproaching; censure mingled with contempt; contumelious or opprobrious language toward any person; abusive reflections; as, severe reproach.
Expressing or containing reproach; upbraiding; opprobrious; abusive.
Not enduring proof or trial; not of standard purity or fineness; disallowed; rejected.
The act of reprobating; the state of being reprobated; strong disapproval or censure.

To produce again, by generation or the like; to cause the existence of (something of the same class, kind, or nature as another thing); to generate or beget, as offspring; as, to reproduce a rose; some animals are reproduced by gemmation.
That which is reproduced.
An expression of blame or censure; especially, blame expressed to the face; censure for a fault; chiding; reproach.
To disprove; to refute.
In a reproving manner.
To prune again or anew.
The act of creeping.
Creeping; moving on the belly, or by means of small and short legs.
Hence: Groveling; low; vulgar; as, a reptile race or crew; reptile vices.
Consonant with the principles of a republic; as, republican sentiments or opinions; republican manners.
A member of the Republican party.
Attachment to, or political sympathy for, a republican form of government.

A second publication, or a new publication of something before published, as of a former will, of a volume already published, or the like; specifically, the publication in one country of a work first issued in another; a reprint.
Admitting of repudiation; fit or proper to be put away.
To cast off; to disavow; to have nothing to do with; to renounce; to reject.
One who favors repudiation, especially of a public debt.
To fight against; to oppose; to resist.
To oppose; to fight against.
To repel; to beat or drive back; as, to repulse an assault; to repulse the enemy.
The act of repelling or driving back; also, the state of being repelled or driven back.
One who repulses, or drives back.
The act of repulsing or repelling, or the state of being repulsed or repelled.
A feeling of violent offence or disgust; repugnance.
Cold; forbidding; offensive; as, repulsive manners.
To buy back or again; to regain by purchase.
Having, or worthy of, good repute; held in esteem; honorable; praiseworthy; as, a reputable man or character; reputable conduct.
The estimation in which one is held; character in public opinion; the character attributed to a person, thing, or action; repute.
To hold in thought; to account; to estimate; to hold; to think; to reckon.
Not having good repute; disreputable; disgraceful; inglorius.
The act of asking for anything desired; expression of desire or demand; solicitation; prayer; petition; entreaty.
That which is asked for or requested.
To address with a request; to ask.
To quicken anew; to reanimate; to give new life to.
Capable of being required; proper to be required.
That which is required; an imperative or authoritative command; an essential condition; something needed or necessary; a need.
That which is required, or is necessary; something indispensable.
That which is required by authority; especially, a quota of supplies or necessaries.
To present a requisition to; to summon request; as, to requisition a person to be a candidate.
Expressing or implying demand.
One who makes reqisition; esp., one authorized by a requisition to investigate facts.

The act of requiting; also, that which requites; return, good or bad, for anything done; in a good sense, compensation; recompense; as, the requital of services; in a bad sense, retaliation, or punishment; as, the requital of evil deeds.
Armor for the upper part of the arm.
A screen or partition wall behind an altar.
To reiterate many times.
A thing; the particular thing; a matter; a point.
A sale at second hand, or at retail; also, a second sale.
To saw again; specifically, to saw a balk, or a timber, which has already been squared, into dimension lumber, as joists, boards, etc.
To ransom; to release; to rescue.
To cut off; to abrogate; to annul.
Specifically, to vacate or make void, as an act, by the enacting authority or by superior authority; to repeal; as, to rescind a law, a resolution, or a vote; to rescind a decree or a judgment.
The act of rescinding; rescission.
The act of rescinding, abrogating, annulling, or vacating; as, the rescission of a law, decree, or judgment.
Tending to rescind; rescinding.
To write over again.
The answer of an emperor when formallyconsulted by particular persons on some difficult question; hence, an edict or decree.

To free or deliver from any confinement, violence, danger, or evil; to liberate from actual restraint; to remove or withdraw from a state of exposure to evil; as, to rescue a prisoner from the enemy; to rescue seamen from destruction.
The act of rescuing; deliverance from restraint, violence, or danger; liberation.
The party in whose favor a rescue is made.
Diligent inquiry or examination in seeking facts or principles; laborius or continued search after truth; as, researches of human wisdom.
To put a new seat, or new seats, in; as, to reseat a theater; to reseat a chair or trousers.
The act of cutting or paring off.
The removal of the articular extremity of a bone, or of the ends of the bones in a false articulation.
A grayish green color, like that of the flowers of mignonette.
To put in possession again; to reinstate.
The taking of lands into the hands of the king where a general livery, or oustre le main, was formerly mis-sued, contrary to the form and order of law.
Admitting of being compared; like.
That which resembles, or is similar; a representation; a likeness.
To liken; to compare; to represent as like.
So as to resemble; with resemblance or likeness.
To produce again by means of seed.
To send back; as, to resend a gift.
In a bad sense, to take ill; to consider as an injury or affront; to be indignant at
To give forth an odor; to smell; to savor.
With deep sense or strong perception.
With a sense of wrong or affront; with resentment.
The state of holding something in the mind as a subject of contemplation, or of being inclined to reflect upon something; a state consciousness; conviction; feeling; impression.
The act of reserving, or keeping back; concealment, or withholding from disclosure; reserve.
A place in which things are reserved or kept.
Hence, to keep in store for future or special use; to withhold from present use for another purpose or time; to keep; to retain.
That which is reserved, or kept back, as for future use.
Restrained from freedom in words or actions; backward, or cautious, in communicating one's thoughts and feelings; not free or frank.
A member of a reserve force of soldiers or militia.

A place where anything is kept in store; especially, a place where water is collected and kept for use when wanted, as to supply a fountain, a canal, or a city by means of aqueducts, or to drive a mill wheel, or the like.
A small intercellular space, often containing <?/esin, essential oil, or some other secreted matter.
To set again; as, to reset type; to reset copy; to reset a diamond.
The act of resetting.
That which is reset; matter set up again.
One who resets, or sets again.
Act of settling again, or state of being settled again; as, the resettlement of lees.
To ship again; to put on board of a vessel a second time; to send on a second voyage; as, to reship bonded merchandise.
To engage one's self again for service on board of a vessel after having been discharged.
The act of reshipping; also, that which is reshippped.
The place where one resides; an abode; a dwelling or habitation; esp., a settled or permanent home or domicile.
A political agency at a native court in British India, held by an officer styled the Residentl: also, a Dutch commercial colony or province in the East Indies.
A diplomatic representative who resides at a foreign court; -- a term usualy applied to ministers of a rank inferrior to that of ambassadors. See the Note under Minister,4.
Of or pertaining to a residence or residents; as, residential trade.
An ecclesiastic who keeps a certain residence.
The office or condition of a resident.
One who resides in a place.
Pertaining to a residue; remaining after a part is taken.
Consisting of residue; as, residuary matter; pertaining to the residue, or part remaining; as, the residuary advantage of an estate.

To sign back; to return by a formal act; to yield to another; to surrender; -- said especially of office or emolument. Hence, to give up; to yield; to submit; -- said of the wishes or will, or of something valued; -- also often used reflexively.
The state of being resigned or submissive; quiet or patient submission; unresisting acquiescence; as, resignation to the will and providence of God.
One to whom anything is resigned, or in whose favor a resignation is made.
The act of resigning.
To start back; to recoil; to recede from a purpose.
The mechanical work required to strain an elastic body, as a deflected beam, stretched spring, etc., to the elastic limit; also, the work performed by the body in recovering from such strain.

Any one of a class of yellowish brown solid inflammable substances, of vegetable origin, which are nonconductors of electricity, have a vitreous fracture, and are soluble in ether, alcohol, and essential oils, but not in water; specif., pine resin (see Rosin).
Any one of the salts the resinic acids.
Yielding resin; as, a resiniferous tree or vessel.
Having the form of resin.
Containing or exhibiting resinous electricity.
Of or pertaining to resin; of the nature of resin; resembling or obtained from resin.
The quality of being resinous.
Wisdom derived from severe experience; hence, repentance.

The quality of not yielding to force or external pressure; that power of a body which acts in opposition to the impulse or pressure of another, or which prevents the effect of another power; as, the resistance of the air to a body passing through it; the resistance of a target to projectiles.
The quality of being resistible; resistibleness.
The quality of being resistant; resitstance.
Making resistance; opposing; as, a resisting medium.
Incapable of being resisted; irresistible.
Having a decided purpose; determined; resolved; fixed in a determination; hence, bold; firm; steady.

The act, operation, or process of resolving. Specifically: (a) The act of separating a compound into its elements or component parts. (b) The act of analyzing a complex notion, or solving a vexed question or difficult problem.
The state of being relaxed; relaxation.
Serving to dissolve or relax.
The quality or condition of being resolvable; resolvableness.

Admitting of being resolved; admitting separation into constituent parts, or reduction to first principles; admitting solution or explanation; as, resolvable compounds; resolvable ideas or difficulties.
The quality of being resolvable; resolvability.
To separate the component parts of; to reduce to the constituent elements; -- said of compound substances; hence, sometimes, to melt, or dissolve.
To be separated into its component parts or distinct principles; to undergo resolution.
That which has been resolved on or determined; decisive conclusion; fixed purpose; determination; also, legal or official determination; a legislative declaration; a resolution.
That which has the power of resolving, or causing solution; a solvent.
That which has power to disperse inflammatory or other tumors; a discutient; anything which aids the absorption of effused products.
That which clears up and removes difficulties, and makes the mind certain or determined.

A prolongation or increase of any sound, eithar by reflection, as in a cavern or apartment the walls of which are not distant enough to return a distinct echo, or by the production of vibrations in other bodies, as a sounding-board, or the bodies of musical instruments.
Returning, or capable of returning, sound; fitted to resound; resounding; echoing back.

Anything which resounds; specifically, a vessel in the form of a cylinder open at one end, or a hollow ball of brass with two apertures, so contrived as to greatly intensify a musical tone by its resonance. It is used for the study and analysis of complex sounds.
Of, or pertaining to, or producing, resorcin; as, resorcylic acid.
The act of resorbing; also, the act of absorbing again; reabsorption.
Active power or movement; spring.
To fall back; to revert.
A place to which one betakes himself habitually; a place of frequent assembly; a haunt.
To sound loudly; as, his voice resounded far.
To be filled with sound; to ring; as, the woods resound with song.
To praise or celebrate with the voice, or the sound of instruments; to extol with sounds; to spread the fame of.
Pecuniary means; funds; money, or any property that can be converted into supplies; available means or capabilities of any kind.
To answer; to echo.
Esteem; regard; consideration; honor.
Worthy of respect; fitted to awaken esteem; deserving regard; hence, of good repute; not mean; as, a respectable citizen.
The act of respecting; respect; regard.
Looking towardl having reference to; relative, not absolute; as, the respective connections of society.
To sprinkle; to scatter.
The quality or state of being respirable; respirableness.
Suitable for being breathed; adapted for respiration.
The act of respiring or breathing again, or catching one's breath.
Relief from toil or suffering: rest.
Of or pertaining to respiration; as, respirative organs.

A divice of gauze or wire, covering the mouth or nose, to prevent the inhalation of noxious substances, as dust or smoke. Being warmed by the breath, it tempers cold air passing through it, and may also be used for the inhalation of medicated vapors.
Of or pertaining to respiration; serving for respiration; as, the respiratory organs; respiratory nerves; the respiratory function; respiratory changes.
Temporary intermission of labor, or of any process or operation; interval of rest; pause; delay.
To relieve by a pause or interval of rest
To say somethin in return; to answer; to reply; as, to respond to a question or an argument.
To show some effect in return to a force; to act in response; to accord; to correspond; to suit.
To suit or accord with; to correspond to.
A short anthem sung at intervals during the reading of a chapter.
One who is answerable or responsible.
An answer or reply.
The state of being responsible, accountable, or answerable, as for a trust, debt, or obligation.
That for which anyone is responsible or accountable; as, the resonsibilities of power.
Able to respond or answer for one's conduct and obligations; trustworthy, financially or otherwise; as, to have a responsible man for surety.
The first university examination; -- called also little go. See under Little, a.
Suited to something else; correspondent.
An antiphonary; a response book.
A state of quiet or repose; a cessation from motion or labor; tranquillity; as, rest from mental exertion; rest of body or mind.
Those not included in a proposition or description; the remainder; others.
The keeper of an eathing house or a restaurant.
To stem, or as, to restem a current.
Giving rest; freeing from toil, trouble, etc.
A restive or stubborn horse.
Formed like a rope; -- applied especially to several ropelike bundles or masses of fibers on the dorsal side of the medulla oblongata.
In a resty manner.
Act of quenching or extingishing.
The quality or state of being resty; sluggishness.
The act of restoring anything to its rightful owner, or of making good, or of giving an equivalent for any loss, damage, or injury; indemnification.
Unwilling to go on; obstinate in refusing to move forward; stubborn; drawing back.
Not satisfied to be at rest or in peace; averse to repose or quiet; eager for change; discontented; as, restless schemers; restless ambition; restless subjects.
The belief or doctrines of the Restorationists.
One who believes in a temporary future punishment and a final restoration of all to the favor and presence of God; a Universalist.
Of or pertaining to restoration; having power to restore.
To store again; as, the goods taken out were re-stored.
To bring back to its former state; to bring back from a state of ruin, decay, disease, or the like; to repair; to renew; to recover.
One who, or that which, restores.
To draw back again; to hold back from acting, proceeding, or advancing, either by physical or moral force, or by any interposing obstacle; to repress or suppress; to keep down; to curb.
The act of restraining.
The act or process of restraining, or of holding back or hindering from motion or action, in any manner; hindrance of the will, or of any action, physical or mental.
The state of being restrained.
To restrain within bounds; to limit; to confine; as, to restrict worlds to a particular meaning; to restrict a patient to a certain diet.
That which restricts; limitation; restraint; as, restrictions on trade.
Serving or tending to restrict; limiting; as, a restrictive particle; restrictive laws of trade.
Quality or state of being restringent; astringency.
Disposed to rest; indisposed toexercton; sluggish; also, restive.
Act of sweating again.
To leap back; to rebound.
To come out, or have an issue; to terminate; to have consequences; -- followed by in; as, this measure will result in good or in evil.

That which results; the conclusion or end to which any course or condition of things leads, or which is obtained by any process or operation; consequence or effect; as, the result of a course of action; the result of a mathematical operation.
Capable of, or admitting of, being resumed.
The act of resuming; as, the resumption of a grant, of delegated powers, of an argument, of specie payments, etc.
The taking again into the king's hands of such lands or tenements as he had granted to any man on false suggestions or other error.
Inverted in position; appearing to be upside down or reversed, as the flowers of the orchis and the leaves of some plants.
The state of luing on the back; the state of being resupinate, or reversed.
The act of rising again; resurrection.
Rising again, as from the dead.
To reanimate; to restore to life; to bring to view (that which was forgotten or lost).
Especially, the rising again from the dead; the resumption of life by the dead; as, the resurrection of Jesus Christ; the general resurrection of all the dead at the Day of Judgment.
To raise from the dead.
Capable of resuscitation; as, resuscitable plants.
To come to life again; to revive.
One who, or that which, resuscitates.
The sale of commodities in small quantities or parcels; -- opposed to wholesale; sometimes, the sale of commodities at second hand.
Done at retail; engaged in retailing commodities; as a retail trade; a retail grocer.
To sell in small quantities, as by the single yard, pound, gallon, etc.; to sell directly to the consumer; as, to retail cloth or groceries.
To sell at second hand.
The act of retailing.
To continue to hold; to keep in possession; not to lose, part with, or dismiss; to retrain from departure, escape, or the like.
To keep; to continue; to remain.
The act of retaining; retention.
One who, or that which, retains.
One who is retained or kept in service; an attendant; an adherent; a hanger-on.
To take from a captor; to recapture; as, to retake a ship or prisoners.
The act of retaliating, or of returning like for like; retribution; now, specifically, the return of evil for evil; e.g., an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth.
Tending to, or involving, retaliation; retaliative; as retaliatory measures.

To keep delaying; to continue to hinder; to prevent from progress; to render more slow in progress; to impede; to hinder; as, to retard the march of an army; to retard the motion of a ship; -- opposed to accelerate.
To put off; to postpone; as, to retard the attacks of old age; to retard a rupture between nations.
That which retards; an obstacle; an obstruction.
One who, or that which, retards.
The act of retarding; retardation.
Act of disclosing or uncovering something concealed.
A white crystalline hydrocarbon, polymeric with benzene. It is extracted from pine tar, and is also found in certain fossil resins.
That which is retained.
The power of retaining; retentiveness.
The quality of being retentive.
The power of retaining; retentive force; as, the retentivity of a magnet.
A muscle which serves to retain an organ or part in place, esp. when retracted. See Illust. of Phylactolemata.
Any one of several species of bryozoans of the genus Retepora. They form delicate calcareous corals, usually composed of thin fenestrated fronds.
To annual, as orders.
Any spider which spins webs to catch its prey.
Constructing or using a web, or net, to catch prey; -- said of certain spiders.
A figure by which a person really speaks of a thing while he makes a show as if he would say nothingon the subject.
Inclined to keep silent; reserved; uncommunicative.
A reticule. See Reticule,2.
Of or pertaining to a reticulum.
One of the Reticularia.
In a reticular manner.
Resembling network; having the form or appearance of a net; netted; as, a reticulated structure.
Having veins, fibers, or lines crossing like the threads or fibers of a network; as, a reticulate leaf; a reticulated surface; a reticulated wing of an insect.
A system of wires or lines in the focus of a telescope or other instrument; a reticle.
Forming a network; characterized by a reticulated sructure.
Composed of crossing lines and interstices; reticular; netlike; as, the retiform coat of the eye.
The delicate membrane by which the back part of the globe of the eye is lined, and in which the fibers of the optic nerve terminate. See Eye.
One of the retractor muscles of the proboscis of certain worms.
That part of the eye of an invertebrate which corresponds in function with the retina of a vertebrate.
Of or pertaining to resin; derived from resin; specifically, designating an acid found in certain fossil resins and hydrocarbons.
An inflammable mineral resin, usually of a yellowish brown color, found in roundish masses, sometimes with coal.
Inflammation of the retina.
Resinlike, or resinform; resembling a resin without being such.
A hydrocarbon oil obtained by the distillation of resin, -- used in printer's ink.

One of group of two to four united cells which occupy the axial part of the ocelli, or ommatidia, of the eyes of invertebrates, and contain the terminal nerve fibrill\'91. See Illust. under Ommatidium.
Of or pertaining to retinophor\'91.
The study of the retina of the eye by means of the ophthalmoscope.
The body of retainers who follow a prince or other distinguished person; a train of attendants; a suite.
Having, or characterized by, retinul<?/.
A bird having small polygonal scales covering the tarsi.
Retirement; -- mostly used in a jocose or burlesque way.
To withdraw; to take away; -- sometimes used reflexively.
Withdrawn from active duty or business; as, a retired officer; a retired physician.
Reserved; shy; not forward or obtrusive; as, retiring modesty; retiring manners.
Of or pertaining to retirement; causing retirement; suited to, or belonging to, retirement.
A group of spiders which spin irregular webs; -- called also Retitelari\'91.
imp. & p. p. of Retell.
To bend or curve back; as, a retorted line.
To throw back; to reverberate; to reflect.

A vessel in which substances are subjected to distillation or decomposition by heat. It is made of different forms and materials for different uses, as a bulb of glass with a curved beak to enter a receiver for general chemical operations, or a cylinder or semicylinder of cast iron for the manufacture of gas in gas works.
Act of retorting or throwing back; reflection or turning back.
To toss back or again.
To touch again, or rework, in order to improve; to revise; as, to retouch a picture or an essay.
To correct or change, as a negative, by handwork.
To trace back, as a line.
Ti withdraw; to recall; to disavow; to recant; to take back; as, to retract an accusation or an assertion.
To take back what has been said; to withdraw a concession or a declaration.
Capable of being retracted; retractile.
To retract; to recant.
The act of retracting what has been said; recantation.
CApable of retraction; capable of being drawn back or up; as, the claws of a cat are retractile.
The act of retracting, or drawing back; the state of being retracted; as, the retraction of a cat's claws.
The act of withdrawing something advanced, stated, claimed, or done; declaration of change of opinion; recantation.
That which retracts, or withdraws.
One who, or that which, retracts.
To translate anew; especially, to translate back into the original language.
The withdrawing, or open renunciation, of a suit in court by the plaintiff, by which he forever lost his right of action.
The act of retiring or withdrawing one's self, especially from what is dangerous or disagreeable.
The place to which anyone retires; a place or privacy or safety; a refuge; an asylum.
To lessen; to abridge; to curtail; as, to retrench superfluities or expenses.
The act or process of retrenching; as, the retrenchment of words in a writing.

A work constructed within another, to prolong the defense of the position when the enemy has gained possession of the outer work; or to protect the defenders till they can retreat or obtain terms for a capitulation.
To pay back; to give in return, as payment, reward, or punishment; to requite; as, to retribute one for his kindness; to retribute just punishment to a criminal.
The act of retributing; repayment.
That which is given in repayment or compensation; return suitable to the merits or deserts of, as an action; commonly, condign punishment for evil or wrong.
That may be retrieved or recovered; admitting of retrieval.
To find again; to recover; to regain; to restore from loss or injury; as, to retrieve one's character; to retrieve independence.
The recovery of game once sprung; -- an old sporting term.
A dor, or a breed of dogs, chiefly employed to retrieve, or to find and recover game birds that have been killed or wounded.
A prefix or combining form signifying backward, back; as, retroact, to act backward; retrospect, a looking back.
To act backward, or in return; to act in opposition; to be retrospective.
Action returned, or action backward.
Operation on something past or preceding.
To cede or grant back; as, to retrocede a territory to a former proprietor.
Disposed or likely to retrocede; -- said of diseases which go from one part of the body to another, as the gout.
The act of retroceding.
The state of being retroceded, or granted back.
Copulating backward, or from behind.
Reflexed; bent or turned abruptly backward.
The act of reflexing; the state of being retroflexed. Cf. Retroversion.
Refracted; as, a retrofract stem.
Begetting young by retrocopulation.
The act of retrograding, or moving backward.
The state of being retrograde; decline.
Hence, to decline from a better to a worse condition, as in morals or intelligence.

Backward development; a passing from a higher to a lower state of organization or structure, as when an animal, approaching maturity, becomes less highly organized than would be expected from its earlier stages or known relationship. Called also retrograde development, and regressive metamorphism.
Passing from a higher to a lower condition; declining from a more perfect state of organization; regressive.
The quality or state of being retromingent.
Bent backward or downward.
To look backward; hence, to affect or concern what is past.
Looking backward; contemplating things past; -- opposed to prospective; as, a retrospective view.
Having reference to what is past; affecting things past; retroactive; as, a retrospective law.
The inoculation of a cow with human vaccine virus.
A turning or bending backward; also, the state of being turned or bent backward; displacement backwards; as, retroversion of the uterus.
In a state of retroversion.
A place where flax is retted; a rettery.
To turn back; to go or come again to the same place or condition.
To repay; as, to return borrowed money.
Legally required to be returned, delivered, given, or rendered; as, a writ or precept returnable at a certain day; a verdict returnable to the court.
A second union; union formed anew after separation, secession, or discord; as, a reunion of parts or particles of matter; a reunion of parties or sects.
An assembling of persons who have been separated, as of a family, or the members of a disbanded regiment; an assembly so composed.
To vaccinate a second time or again.
The act of growing well; the state of being revalescent.
A second or new valuation.
To vamp again; hence, topatch up; to reconstruct.

The side of an opening for a window, doorway, or the like, between the door frame or window frame and the outer surface of the wall; or, where the opening is not filled with a door, etc., the whole thickness of the wall; the jamb.
Capable of being revealed.
One who, or that which, reveals.
The beat of drum, or bugle blast, about break of day, to give notice that it is time for the soldiers to rise, and for the sentinels to forbear challenging.
A feast with loose and noisy jollity; riotous festivity or merrymaking; a carousal.
To move playfully; to indulge without restraint.
That which is revealed.
The act of reveling.
Fond of festivity; given to merrymaking or reveling.
A rabble; a riotous assembly; a mob.
The disposition to revenge; a malignant wishing of evil to one who has done us an injury.
Full of, or prone to, revenge; vindictive; malicious; revenging; wreaking revenge.
Hence, return; reward; as, a revenue of praise.
Driven back, as sound; reflected.
To be driven back; to be reflected or repelled, as rays of light; to be echoed, as sound.
Of the nature of reverberation; tending to reverberate; reflective.
Producing reverberation; acting by reverberation; reverberative.
To cover again with verdure.
Expressing reverence, veneration, devotion, or submission; as, reverent words; reverent behavior.
In a reverent manner; in respectful regard.
A loose or irregular train of thought occurring in musing or mediation; deep musing; daydream.

A change or overthrowing; as, the reversal of a judgment, which amounts to an official declaration that it is false; the reversal of an attainder, or of an outlawry, by which the sentence is rendered void.
Turned upside down; greatly disturbed.
That which is directly opposite or contrary to something else; a contrary; an opposite.
To become or be reversed.
Annulled and the contrary substituted; as, a reversed judgment or decree.
The quality of being reversible.
Hence, having a pattern or finished surface on both sides, so that either may be used; -- said of fabrics.
Serving to effect reversal, as of motion; capable of being reversed.
That which reverts or returns; residue.
That which is to be received in reversion.
One who has a reversion, or who is entitled to lands or tenements, after a particular estate granted is terminated.
To turn back, or to the contrary; to reverse.
A remedy which restores the natural order of the inverted irritative motions in the animal system.
Reverting, or tending to revert; returning.
To clothe again; to cover, as with a robe; to robe.
The apartment, in a church or temple, where the vestments, etc., are kept; -- now contracted into vestry.
A facing of wood, stone, or any other material, to sustain an embankment when it receives a slope steeper than the natural slope; also, a retaining wall.
To vibrate back or in return.
To vie with, or rival, in return.
To meet a wager on, as on the taking of a trick, with a higher wager.
To make a retort; to bandy words.
To go over and examine critically or deliberately.
A second or repeated view; a re\'89xamination; a retrospective survey; a looking over again; as, a review of one's studies; a review of life.
An examination with a view to amendment or improvement; revision; as, an author's review of his works.
Having new vigor or strength; invigorated anew.
To address or abuse with opprobrious and contemptuous language; to reproach.
To overcome; to refute, as error.
That may be revised.
The act of revising, or reviewing and re\'89xamining for correction and improvement; revision; as, the revisal of a manuscript; the revisal of a proof sheet; the revisal of a treaty.
To look at again for the detection of errors; to re\'89xamine; to review; to look over with care for correction; as, to revise a writing; to revise a translation.
To compare (a proof) with a previous proof of the same matter, and mark again such errors as have not been corrected in the type.
A second proof sheet; a proof sheet taken after the first or a subsequent correction.
The act of revising; re\'89xamination for correction; review; as, the revision of a book or writing, or of a proof sheet; a revision of statutes.
That which is made by revising.
Having the power or purpose to revise; revising.
The act of reviving, or the state of being revived.
The spirit of religious revivals; the methods of revivalists.

A clergyman or layman who promotes revivals of religion; an advocate for religious revivals; sometimes, specifically, a clergyman, without a particular charge, who goes about to promote revivals. Also used adjectively.
To return to life; to recover life or strength; to live anew; to become reanimated or reinvigorated.
To raise from coma,, languor, depression, or discouragement; to bring into action after a suspension.
One who, or that which, revives.
To revive; to recall or restore to life.
Renewal of life; restoration of life; the act of recaling, or the state of being recalled, to life.
The reduction of a metal from a state of combination to its metallic state.
The act of reviving, or the state of being revived; renewal of life.
Capable of being revoked; as, a revocable edict or grant; a revocable covenant.
The act of calling back, or the state of being recalled; recall.

The act by which one, having the right, annuls an act done, a power or authority given, or a license, gift, or benefit conferred; repeal; reversal; as, the revocation of an edict, a power, a will, or a license.
To refurnish with a voice; to refit, as an organ pipe, so as to restore its tone.
To call or bring back; to recall.
By way of revocation.
To turn away; to abandon or reject something; specifically, to turn away, or shrink, with abhorrence.
To do violence to; to cause to turn away or shrink with abhorrence; to shock; as, to revolt the feelings.
Causing abhorrence mixed with disgust; exciting extreme repugnance; loathsome; as, revolting cruelty.
Capable of revolving; rotatory; revolving.
Return to a point before occupied, or to a point relatively the same; a rolling back; return; as, revolution in an ellipse or spiral.
One engaged in effecting a change of government; a favorer of revolution.
To turn or roll round on, or as on, an axis, like a wheel; to rotate, -- which is the more specific word in this sense.
To move in a curved path round a center; as, the planets revolve round the sun.
The act or state of revolving; revolution.
Making a revolution or revolutions; rotating; -- used also figuratively of time, seasons, etc., depending on the revolution of the earth.
A sudden reaction; a sudden and complete change; -- applied to the feelings.
That which causes revulsion; specifically (Med.), a revulsive remedy or agent.

That which is given in return for good or evil done or received; esp., that which is offered or given in return for some service or attainment, as for excellence in studies, for the return of something lost, etc.; recompense; requital.
Having, or affording, no reward.
To alter the wording of; to restate in other words; as, to reword an idea or a passage.
A minute smooth rodlike or fusiform structure found in the tissues of many Turbellaria.
One of the hard parts forming the ovipositor of insects.
Of or pertaining to the Rhabdoc\'d2la.
A minute calcareous rodlike structure found both at the surface and the bottom of the ocean; -- supposed by some to be a calcareous alga.
One of numerous minute rodlike structures formed of two or more cells situated behind the retinul\'91 in the compound eyes of insects, etc. See Illust. under Ommatidium.
One of the several parts composing a rhabdom.
An extinct division of Hydrozoa which includes the graptolities.
A genus of marine Bryozoa in which the tubular cells have a centralchitinous axis and the tentacles are borne on a bilobed lophophore. It is the type of the order Pterobranchia, or Podostomata
A minute sphere composed of rhabdoliths.
Of or pertaining to the rhachis; as, the rhachidian teeth of a mollusk.

A division of marine gastropods having a retractile proboscis and three longitudinal rows of teeth on the radula. It includes many of the large ornamental shells, as the miters, murices, olives, purpuras, volutes, and whelks. See Illust. in Append.
A branch of inflorescence; the zigzag axis on which the florets are arranged in the spikelets of grasses.

Having gular teeth formed by a peculiar modification of the inferior spines of some of the vertebr\'91, as certain South African snakes (Dasypelits) which swallow birds' eggs and use these gular teeth to crush them.
The continued stem or midrib of a pinnately compound leaf, as in a rose leaf or a fern.
Of or pertaining to Rhadamanthus; rigorously just; as, a Rhadamanthine judgment.
One of the three judges of the internal regions; figuratively, a strictly just judge.
Pertining to, or of the same horizon as, certain Mesozoic strata of the Rhetain Alps. These strata are regarded as closing the Triassic period. See the Chart of Geology.
A variety of the mineral cyanite.

Of or pertaining to a natural order of shrubs and trees (Rhamnace\'91, or Rhamne\'91) of which the buckthorn (Rhamnus) is the type. It includes also the New Jersey tea, the supple-jack, and one of the plants called lotus (Zizyphus).
A genus of shrubs and small trees; buckthorn. The California Rhamnus Purchianus and the European R. catharticus are used in medicine. The latter is used for hedges.
A genus of pterodactyls in which the elongated tail supported a leathery expansion at the tip.
The horny covering of the bill of birds.
The continuation of the seed stalk along the side of an anatropous ovule or seed, forming a ridge or seam.
Of or pertaining to rhapsody; consisting of rhapsody; hence, confused; unconnected.
Anciently, one who recited or composed a rhapsody; especially, one whose profession was to recite the verses of Hormer and other epic poets.
Hence, one who recites or sings poems for a livelihood; one who makes and repeats verses extempore.
A recitation or song of a rhapsodist; a portion of an epic poem adapted for recitation, or usually recited, at one time; hence, a division of the Iliad or the Odyssey; -- called also a book.
A disconnected series of sentences or statements composed under excitement, and without dependence or natural connection; rambling composition.
Any one of three species of large South American ostrichlike birds of the genera Rhea and Pterocnemia. Called also the American ostrich.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (commonly called chrysophanic acid) found in rhubarb (Rheum).
One of the berries or drupes of the European buckthorn; also, the buckthorn itself.
Having a verb for its base; derived from a verb; as, rhematic adjectives.
A metallic wire used for regulating the resistance of a circuit, or varying the strength of an electric current, by inserting a greater or less length of it in the circuit.
An instrument for measuring currents, especially the force or intensity of electrical currents; a galvanometer.
An instrument for measuring the velocity of the blood current in the arteries.
A connecting wire of an electric or voltaic apparatus, traversed by a current.
An instrument for detecting the presence or movement of currents, as of electricity.
A contrivance for adjusting or regulating the strength of electrical currents, operating usually by the intercalation of resistance which can be varied at will.
An instrument which periodically or otherwise interrupts an electric current.
A monkey; the bhunder.
Oratory; the art of speaking with propriety, elegance, and force.
A teacher of rhetoric.
A serous or mucous discharge, especially one from the eves or nose.
Of or pertaining to rheumatism; as, rheumatic pains or affections; affected with rheumatism; as, a rheumatic old man; causing rheumatism; as, a rheumatic day.
A general disease characterized by painful, often multiple, local inflammations, usually affecting the joints and muscles, but also extending sometimes to the deeper organs, as the heart.
Of or resembling rheum or rheumatism.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, rheum.
Of or pertaining to rheum; abounding in, or causing, rheum; affected with rheum.
Og or pertaining to the nose or olfactory organs.
A water course; a ditch.
The division of the brain in front of the prosencephalon, consisting of the two olfactory lobes from which the olfactory nerves arise.
Infllammation of the nose; esp., inflammation of the mucous membrane of the nostrils.
Gold and silver, or money.
Of or pertaining to the rhinoceros; resembling the rhinoceros, or his horn.
A concretion formed within the cavities of the nose.
Of or pertaining to rhinology.
One skilled in rhinology.
The science which treats of the nose, and its diseases.
Any species of the genus Rhinilophus, or family Rhinolophid\'91, having a horseshoe-shaped nasal crest; a horseshoe bat.
Like or pertaining to the rhinolophids, or horseshoe bats.

One of the two tentacle-like organs on the back of the head or neck of a nudibranch or tectibranch mollusk. They are usually retractile, and often transversely furrowed or plicate, and are regarded as olfactory organs. Called also dorsal tentacles. See Illust.  under Pygobranchia, and Opisthobranchia.
Of or pertaining to rhinoplasty; as, a rhinoplastic operation.
Plastic surgery of the nose to correct deformity or to replace lost tissue. Tissue may be transplanted from the patient's cheek, forehead, arm, etc., or even from another person.
Any old-world bat of the genus Rhinopoma. The rhinopomes have a long tail extending beyond the web, and inhabit caves and tombs.

A rare disease of the skin, characterized by the development of very hard, more or less flattened, prominences, appearing first upon the nose and subsequently upon the neighboring parts, esp. the lips, palate, and throat.
Of or pertaining to rhinoscopy.
The examination or study of the soft palate, posterior nares, etc., by means of a laryngoscopic mirror introduced into the pharynx.
The sheath of the upper mandible of a bird.
A division of gastropod mollusks having a large number of long, divergent, hooklike, lingual teeth in each transverse row. It includes the scutibranchs. See Illustration in Appendix.
One of the Rhipiptera, a group of insects having wings which fold like a fan; a strepsipter.
Producing flowers from a rootstock, or apparently from a root.
A rootlike filament or hair growing from the stems of mosses or on lichens; a rhizoid.
Having perennial rootstocks or bulbs, but annual flowering stems; -- said of all perennial herbs.
A division of Pectostraca including saclike parasites of Crustacea. They adhere by rootlike extensions of the head. See Illusration in Appendix.
A reptile whose teeth are rooted in sockets, as the crocodile.
One of a proposed class of flowering plants growning on the roots of other plants and destitute of green foliage.
Having the nature or habit of a rhizome or rootstock.
A rootstock. See Rootstock.
A division of marsupials. The wombat is the type.
Feeding on roots; root-eating.
A genus of trees including the mangrove. See Mangrove.
One of the Rhizopoda.
Of or pertaining to the rhizopods.
A suborder of Medus\'91 which includes very large species without marginal tentacles, but having large mouth lobes closely united at the edges. See Illust. in Appendix.
One of the Rhizostomata.
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, rhodium and ammonia; -- said of certain complex compounds.
A salt of rhodanic acid; a sulphocyanate.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (commonly called sulphocyanic acid) which frms a red color with ferric salts.
Of or pertaining to Rhodes, an island of the Mediterranean.
Of or pertaining to rhodium; containing rhodium.

A rare element of the light platinum group. It is found in platinum ores, and obtained free as a white inert metal which it is very difficult to fuse. Symbol Rh. Atomic weight 104.1.  Specific gravity 12.

Pertaining to, or designating, a colorless crystalline substance (called rhodizonic acid, and carboxylic acid) obtained from potassium carboxide and from certain quinones. It forms brilliant red, yellow, and purple salts.
Manganese carbonate, a rose-red mineral sometimes occuring crystallized, but generally massive with rhombohedral cleavage like calcite; -- called also dialogite.
A genus of shrubs or small trees, often having handsome evergreen leaves, and remarkable for the beauty of their flowers; rosebay.
Manganese spar, or silicate of manganese, a mineral occuring crystallised and in rose-red masses. It is often used as an ornamental stone.
The red pigment contained in the inner segments of the cones of the retina in animals. See Chromophane.
Any seaweed with red spores.
A dicyemid which produces infusorialike embryos; -- opposed to nematogene. See Dicyemata.
Related to the rhombohedron; presenting the form of a rhombohedron, or a form derivable from a rhombohedron; relating to a system of forms including the rhombohedron and scalenohedron.
A solid contained by six rhomboids; a parallelopiped.
An oblique-angled parallelogram like a rhomb, but having only the opposite sides equal, the length and with being different.
Having, or approaching, the shape of a rhomboid.
A variety of dolomite.
Same as Rhomb, 1.
Of or pertaining to a rhonchus; produced by rhonchi.

An adventitious whistling or snoring sound heard on auscultation of the chest when the air channels are partially obstructed. By some writers the term rhonchus is used as equivalent to r\'83le in its widest sense. See R\'83le.
Applied to a line or verse in which each successive word has one more syllable than the preceding.
One of the marginal sensory bodies of medus\'91 belonging to the Discophora.
A division of Lepidoptera including all the butterflies. They differ from other Lepidoptera in having club-shaped antenn\'91.
An oversounding, or a misuse, of the letter r; specifically (Phylol.), the tendency, exhibited in the Indo-European languages, to change s to r, as wese to were.
The name of several large perennial herbs of the genus Rheum and order Polygonace\'91.
The large and fleshy leafstalks of Rheum Rhaponticum and other species of the same genus. They are pleasantly acid, and are used in cookery. Called also pieplant.
A line which crosses successive meridians at a constant angle; -- called also rhumb line, and loxodromic curve. See Loxodromic.
A mixtire of caustic lime and orpiment, or tersulphide of arsenic, -- used in the depilation of hides.
To influence by rhyme.
A rhymer; a maker of poor poetry.
A rhymer; a rhymester.

An order of reptiles having biconcave vertebr\'91, immovable quadrate bones, and many other peculiar osteological characters. Hatteria is the only living genus, but numerous fossil genera are known, some of which are among the earliest of reptiles. See Hatteria. Called also Rhynchocephalia.
A fossil cephalopod beak.
A genus of brachiopods of which some species are still living, while many are found fossil.
A group of Coleoptera having a snoutlike head; the snout beetles, curculios, or weevils.
One of the Rhynchophora.
A quartzose trachyte, an igneous rock often showing a fluidal structure.
In ancient art, the painting of genre or still-life pictures.
An instrument, acting on the principle of Pitot's tube, for measuring the velocity of a fluid current, the speed of a ship, etc.
In the widest sense, a dividing into short portions by a regular succession of motions, impulses, sounds, accents, etc., producing an agreeable effect, as in music poetry, the dance, or the like.
Movement in musical time, with periodical recurrence of accent; the measured beat or pulse which marks the character and expression of the music; symmetry of movement and accent.
The department of musical science which treats of the length of sounds.
Writing rhythm; verse making.
A Spanish coin. See Real.
That which resembles a rib in form or use.
To inclose, as with ribs, and protect; to shut in.
The talk of a ribald; low, vulgar language; indecency; obscenity; lewdness; -- now chiefly applied to indecent language, but formerly, as by Chaucer, also to indecent acts or conduct.
A huge bow fixed on the wall of a fortified town for casting javelins.
Intercalated with slate; -- said of a seam of coal.
A fillet or narrow woven fabric, commonly of silk, used for trimming some part of a woman's attire, for badges, and other decorative purposes.
A narrow strip or shred; as, a steel or magnesium ribbon; sails torn to ribbons.
The principles and practices of the Ribbonmen.  See Ribbon Society, under Ribbon.
A member of the Ribbon Society. See Ribbon Society, under Ribbon.
A malvaceous tree (Hoheria populnea) of New Zealand, the bark of which is used for cordage.
A genus of shrubs including gooseberries and currants of many kinds.
A sort of stringed instrument; a rebec.
An old woman; -- in contempt.
A species of plantain (Plantago lanceolata) with long, narrow, ribbed leaves; -- called also rib grass, ripple grass, ribwort plantain.
A suffix signifying dominion, jurisdiction; as, bishopric, the district over which a bishop exercises authority.
Any one of numerous species of small white polished marine shells of the genus Olivella.
Having an abundance of material possessions; possessed of a large amount of property; well supplied with land, goods, or money; wealthy; opulent; affluent; -- opposed to poor.
That which appears rich, sumptuous, precious, or the like.
The quality or state of being rich (in any sense of the adjective).
An herb (Pilea pumila) of the Nettle family, having a smooth, juicy, pellucid stem; -- called also clearweed.
Pertaining to, or designating, an isomeric modification of ricinoleic acid obtained as a white crystalline solid.
The glycerin salt of ricinelaidic acid, obtained as a white crystalline waxy substance by treating castor oil with nitrous acid.
Pertaining to, or derived from, castor oil; formerly, designating an acid now called ricinoleic acid.
A bitter white crystalline alkaloid extracted from the seeds of the castor-oil plant.
A salt of ricinoleic acid; -- formerly called palmate.
Pertaining to, or designating, a fatty acid analogous to oleic acid, obtained from castor oil as an oily substance, Cricinolic.
The glycerin salt of ricinoleic acid, occuring as a characteristic constituent of castor oil; -- formerly called palmin.

A genus of plants of the Spurge family, containing but one species (R. communis), the castor-oil plant. The fruit is three-celled, and contains three large seeds from which castor oil iss expressed. See Palma Christi.
A stack or pile, as of grain, straw, or hay, in the open air, usually protected from wet with thatching.
A stout pole for use in making a rick, or for a spar to a boat.
Feeble in the joints; imperfect; weak; shaky.
